Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Information Architectures for Femto-Aided Cellular Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Femto-aided cellular networks appear to be one the best solutions to achieve multi-fold capacity needed for future wireless networks. However, Femto-aided cellular systems have an information architecture that is very different from current planned and centrally managed cellular architecture. In this project, both the design of information architecture to acquire network state information and the optimal use of the resulting NSI will be addressed. The project is organized into three symbiotic research thrusts on network-aware physical-layer (PHY) coding schemes, network protocols and algorithms leveraging advanced PHYs, and their architectural prototypes. The first thrust utilizes recent innovations in deterministic models of wireless networks and develops novel physical-layer cooperative encoding and decoding schemes that operate with delayed, inconsistent, and erroneous NSI. The second thrust builds on the new physical-layer coding schemes to design network-scheduling algorithms to address performance issues. Finally, the third thrust utilizes the WARP programmable radios and studies implementation challenges of the protocols. The project goals of foundational design for Femto-aided cellular networks will have significant impact on industry practice. The PIs will facilitate technology transfer through their established industry affiliate program. A broad range of education and outreach activities will also complement the research agenda, including integration of research findings into the courses, promoting underrepresented and undergraduate populations, and engaging with the middle/high school community to raise the level of interest in engineering and mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: Femto­-aided cellular networks are fundamentally altering the landscape of commercial wireless deployments. From a planned and centrally managed cellular network architecture, we are devolving to a heterogenous (cellular base­ stations and Femto base­stations) unplanned network, with loose coordination due to disparate time­scales and bandwidths in the backhaul interconnects between these nodes. From an operational perspective, this results in a vastly different information architecture, i.e., who knows what and when, from current cellular architectures. This places us squarely in a setting where Network State Information (NSI ­ traffic, channel quality, topology, statistics) is noisy, partially missing, delayed, and inconsistent across nodes. This project addresses the challenge of developing advanced information architectures through three inter­related thrusts: (i) advanced network-­aware physical layers (ii) network protocols leveraging advanced PHYs, and operational designs and prototypes.

To address above challenges, the Rice team designed, developed and evaluated three innovative ideas. First, we developed theoretical foundations to understand how the lack of complete network state information impacts network capacity. This was the first-of-its-kind analysis, requiring us to develop novel network models. Second, we developed protocols to manage partial network state information, so that the resulting network can achieve the capacity limits derived with theory. Lastly, we developed several physical layer techniques to operate with partial information but out-perform their current counterparts. To achieve higher performance with less information, we relied on the new concept of full-duplex wireless.

Broader Impacts: The project led to following broader impacts. The new physical layer techniques leveraging full-duplex are being considered by next-generation standards to increase the spectral efficiency of 5G networks. The project produced multiple conferences and journal publications, including some highly cited papers. It provided a multidisciplinary platform for undergraduate and graduate education and research, including students from underrepresented populations.
